Graphical abstract The oxygen vacancy and mid-gap in N-doped Fe2(MoO4)3 significantly enhanced the photocatalytic ability of tetracyclines under visible light irradiation. A novel non-metal doped Fe2(MoO4)3 photocatalyst with flower-like microstructure was synthesized by a hydrothermal method. The incorporation location of nitrogen was proved by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) revealed mid-gap from the dope of nitrogen strongly enhanced the visible-light absorption ability. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) showed that the morphology of doped samples was greatly influenced by nitrogen dopant. Significantly, N-doped Fe2(MoO4)3 exhibits an ideal tetracycline (TC) photocatalytic ability, which can be a potential function material for antibiotics degradation. Photoluminescence (PL) and photocurrent indicated that constract of oxygen vacancy, which modified the surficial chemistry micro-circumstance, greatly depressed the recombination rate of the photo-generated electron–hole pairs. In order to investigate the possible mechanism of promoted TC degradation efficiency, radical trapping experiments of pure Fe2(MoO4)3 and N-doped samples were examined. It was found that superoxide radicals (·O2 −) and hydroxyl radical (·OH) formed in the visible light excitation process play an important role in the fragmentation reaction. Moreover, the possible ring-opening intermediates were deduced and a reasonable enhancement mechanism of N-doped Fe2(MoO4)3 TC degradation was also investigated in this study. This investigation could provide an effective reference for doping non-metallic species for improving the photocatalytic activity of Fe2(MoO4)3. Keywords Photocatalytic Nitrogen-doped Fe2(MoO4)3 Oxygen vacancy Tetracyclines 1 Introduction Semiconductor photocatalysis technology has attracted continuous attention as a green approach because it can be widely applied in the areas of carbon dioxide reduction [1,2], water splitting [3,4], and organics decomposition. There is no doubt that semiconductor TiO2 is one of the most widely used photocatalysts. However, the practical application of TiO2 is significantly limited because the band gap of TiO2 is 3.2eV, which is so wide that can only respond to UV light, and only about 4% of the whole sunlight spectrum is UV light, while visible light occupies 43% of the sunlight spectrum. So tremendous efforts have been made to investigate novel visible-light-driven (VLD) photocatalysts, such as BiOX (X=Cl, Br), MoS2, BiVO4, Bi2WO6, Fe2(MoO4)3, and so on [5–9] As one of the most remarkable functional materials, molybdates have been widely used as photoluminescence material, scintillators, matrix for tunable laser, and so on, owing to their chemical stability and the possibility to form different polymorphs [10]. Among the different molybdate groups, the group of transition metal oxides has been used in important applications such as optical fibers [11], Fenton ingredient [12], and catalysts [13]. Nanosized Fe2(MoO4)3, in particular, was generally used as an efficient catalyst in formaldehyde synthesis process [14,15]. Meanwhile, it also presents a variety of applications including rechargeable sodium ion battery [16], H2S gas sensing [17], and preparation of alloys [18]. Recently, Fe2(MoO4)3 has been reported as a potential VLD photocatalyst because of the low cost, high stability, and appropriate CB and VB position [19–21], and the narrow band gap near 2.2eV guarantees the considerable visible-light absorption ability. Pancake-like Fe2(MoO4)3 synthesized by Zhang et al. [10] via microwave-assisted hydrothermal method and applied the powder in photocatalytic degradation of bromopyrogallol red. Fe2(MoO4)3 acts as photo-Fenton-like catalysts synthesized by Tian et al. degraded [9] various dyes in a wide pH range. These results indicated that Fe2(MoO4)3 exhibits the ability of degrade a variety of organic pollutant under the visible light irradiation and may find applications in water pollution control. However, its rapid recombination of the electron–hole pairs seriously restricts the application of photocatalyst. In order to solve the shackle, most researchers concentrate on doping metal cations [22] and the formation of heterojunction [23]. For example, action element Bi has been used as a metal dopant for boosting the photocatalytic activity of Fe2(MoO4)3 [24]. MoO3/Fe2(MoO4)3 heterojunction has been studied and displays significantly enhanced photocatalytic ability. Nevertheless, anions of non-metallic elements with variable valence have never been reported as dopant species so far as we know. Non-metallic species dopants have been proved to be an efficient strategy in several function materials. Nitrogen is one of the most attractive non-metallic species dopants. The dope of nitrogen overcomes the shuttle effect and enables the practical application of Li-S batteries [25]; active sites of nitrogen-doped materials for reduction reaction were also investigated [26]. Researchers have found that N-doped TiO2 significantly improved the photocatalytic ability [27]; dopant nitrogen also acts as an electron transfer channel for reducing the recombination of the photo-generated electron–hole pairs in graphene/Cds nanocomposites [28]. In addition, the previous research of our group investigated the synergistic effect of nitrogen and samarium in Bi2WO6 photocatalyst [29]. Dope of nitrogen mix the 2p state of nitrogen and 2p state of other non-metallic elements from pure catalysts, which modified the top of the valence band and create a novel mid-gap [30]. This mid-gap reduces the band gap and shifts the solar spectrum absorption towards the visible light direction. For nitrogen-doped Fe2(MoO4)3 system, nitrogen presents −3 valence state replace oxygen with -2 valence state, in this case, oxygen vacancy could be formed to capture photo-generated electrons to keep the electric neutrality of Fe2(MoO4)3, this capture behavior modified the surficial chemistry micro-circumstance and leads to the separation of photo-generated electron–hole pairs to restrain the recombination rate. Therefore, doping nitrogen in Fe2(MoO4)3 could be a possible positive strategy to obtain a high efficient VLD photocatalyst. Herein we reported the N-doped Fe2(MoO4)3 flower-like photocatalysts first time prepared by a hydrothermal method. The photocatalytic activity of as-prepared samples was evaluated by TCs under the visible light irradiation. The result indicates that N-doped Fe2(MoO4)3 samples exhibit an enhanced photocatalytic ability compared with that of pure Fe2(MoO4)3 samples. Modified surficial chemistry micro-circumstance efficiently depresses the recombination rate of photo-generated electron–hole pairs guarantee sufficient radicals in organic pollutant degradation reaction. Furthermore, a possible mechanism of the promoted photocatalytic activity was also discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the photocatalysts All the reagents utilized in this study were of analytical grade (Sinopharm Chemical Reagents Co., Ltd, China) and used without further purify process. Pure Fe2(MoO4)3 and N-doped Fe2(MoO4)3 photocatalysts were synthesized through a hydrothermal method, and the general synthesis processes were described: proportionate amounts of sodium molybdate (Na2MoO4·H2O), ferric nitrate (Fe(NO3)3), and carbamide as N source were dissolved in Milli-Q water, respectively. The solution sequence under stirring to form a transparent solution and ensure Fe:Mo=2:3. Adjust the pH value of solution to ca. 5 by NaOH solution. The slurry was stirred for another 30min, then was sealed and transferred into autoclaves. The sealed autoclaves were then heated at 180°C for 12h. N/Fe=10%, 20%, 30%, 40%, and 50% samples were prepared under similar conditions. Then, the products were cooled down to the room temperature naturally and collected by centrifugation. Milli-Q water together with absolute ethanol was used to wash the products several times to make sure that the residual ions were removed. Finally, the product was dried at 80°C for 10h. Pure Fe2(MoO4)3 powder was obtained under the same synthesis process without the introducing of carbamide. To facilitate the description, pure Fe2(MoO4)3 and doped samples aliased as FMO and 10at.% N-FMO, 20at.% N-FMO, 30at.% N-FMO, 40at.% N-FMO, and 50at.% N-FMO hereinafter. 2.2 Characterization of the photocatalysts The phases of crystalline for the as-prepared samples were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (D/MAX-RB; Rigaku, Japan). The patterns of diffraction were detected in the 2θ range from 10 to 55° with a Cu Kα source (λ=1.5418Å) running at 40kV and 30mA. Raman spectra were recorded by a Raman spectrometer (Horiba LabRam; T64000, France) at an excitation wavelength of 532nm. The morphological images of the as-prepared samples were captured using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (S-4800; Hitachi, Japan). Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were detected by a fluorescence spectrophotometer (F-4500; Hitachi, Japan) and the excitation light source was Xe lamp. The UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) of the as-prepared samples were detected under standard conditions using a integrating sphere UV–Vis spectrophotometer (T9s; Persee, China). BaSO4 was utilized as the blank reference. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was examined on an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (ESCALAB 250Xi; Thermo, USA) by an Al Kα radiation. 2.3 Photocatalytic experiment Pure Fe2(MoO4)3 and N-Fe2(MoO4)3 photocatalytic activities under visible light were examined by degrading 20mmolL−1 tetracyclines (TCs). A 400W Xe lamp with a UV cut-off filter (λ >420nm) was used as a light source and fixed about 10cm away from the reactor. The experiments were as follows: 40mg of the photocatalyst was dispersed in 40mL of TC solution; followed by 45min continuous stirring in the dark to achieve an adsorption–desorption balance before light irradiation was introduced in the reaction system. After introducing light source, the reaction samples were collected every 15min. The centrifuge was used to remove the photocatalyst particles. The ratios (C/C0) of the TCs were collected to evaluate the degradation rate (i.e., C 0 was the initial concentration and C was the concentration at a certain time) by scanning the whole wavelength using a UV–Vis spectrophotometer. 2.4 Measurement of photocurrent The measurement of the photocurrent was operated with an electrochemical workstation (5060F; RST, China) by standard three-electrode system, an Ag/AgCl electrode with standard saturated KCl, a Pt wire and prepared samples utilized as the reference electrode, counter electrode, and working electrode, respectively. An Na2SO4 aqueous solution (0.5molL−1) was used as electrolyte. An 80W incandescent light bulb equipped a UV–Vis light cut-off filter was utilized as light source. The detail preparation process of the working electrode is as follows: 10mg samples were dissolved in pre-prepared ethanol and Nafion mixture solution (v/v=50:1), afterwards, spread the solution on the middle of an ITO glass with a round hole, and the diameter of hole is 6mm. Then the photocurrent of the photocatalysts recorded when the light on and off was measured at 0.6V. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 XRD analysis It was reported that two crystalline phases for the as-prepared FMO: orthorhombic type and monoclinic type [31]. In addition, the monoclinic type FMO showed a better photocatalytic ability under visible light irradiation [32]. Fig. 1 shows the XRD diffraction patterns of the pure FMO and N-FMO series photocatalysts. The results indicated that all the prepared samples belong to single monoclinic FMO structure. The characteristic diffraction peaks at 22.83°, 25.69°, 27.49°, and 34.06° of all the patterns at 2θ were indexed as (−1 1 4), (1 2 2), (−2 2 4), and (−1 1 6) planes of FMO based on PDF#35-0183, respectively. The crystalline phases of nitrogen were not detected in the doped photocatalysts. The lattice information and cell volumes of pure FMO and N-FMO were computed from the XRD parameters data to further investigate the change in the crystalline phases and are listed in Table 1 . Based on the literature research [33–35], there are two forms of doping nitrogen: replacing oxygen atoms and filling-in the interval of crystal. The lattice parameter data show that there is an obvious expansion along the c axis for sample 30at.% N-FMO, because of the atomic volume of substitutional nitrogen is larger than that of oxygen, the introduction of nitrogen strengthens the repulsive interaction of atoms, enhanced the spin density of unpaired electron and enlarged the bond distance which lead to the expansion of volume. However, when the doping content of nitrogen over a certain amount, part of nitrogen fill in the intervals of atoms instead of substitution of oxygen, it has a small effect on crystal volume, so that 30at.% N-FMO achieve a maximum volume. Both the lattice expansion and volume increase attributed to the substitution of a larger N3− (171pm) for O2− (132pm) in FMO crystal instead of filling-in the interval, which cannot lead to a volume increase. The data conform to the situation of nitrogen replace oxygen in crystal lattice. For the purpose of further explore the modification of crystal structure in case of nitrogen doping, Raman spectroscopy was accomplished and spectra are illustrated in Fig. 2a and b. The standard group theory for the FMO compound leads to 405 optical modes, along with three acoustic modes at the Brillouin zone center. The optical system is attributed among the irreducible representations of the factor group C 2h, as shown by the equation Γ = 102 A g + 102 B g + 101 A u + 100 B u . Selection rules state that modes belonging to the Ag and Bg irreducible representations are Raman active. In Fig. 2a, there are four different characteristic spectral ranges: 1050-900, 900-700, 500-280, and below 280cm−1, corresponding to the symmetric stretching modes, anti-symmetric stretching modes, bending modes, and lattice modes, respectively [36]. Pure FMO showed an outstanding signal at 780cm−1 and a medium-intensity signal at 960cm−1 corresponding to the Mo-O anti-symmetric stretching and symmetric stretching. The band with lower intensity located at 350cm−1 was confirmed to belong to bending modes. Based on the reported atom coordination and crystal structure information revealed by Raman spectra, the structure model can be observed in Fig. 3 . The structure is composed by MoO4 tetrahedron units connected with FeO6 octahedron units into the unit cell. Both the decrease in the signal intensity and the expansion of the signal for the doped samples with the increase in N content suggest the deformation of the crystal structure after doping. Furthermore, a significant red shift of the signal at about 780cm−1 was observed related to the doping content of nitrogen in the FMO crystal lattice, which indicated that dope of nitrogen chiefly influenced the Mo-O tetrahedron structure. 3.2 Morphology characterization SEM images of pure FMO and N-FMO series photocatalysts were illustrated in Fig. 4 . Pure FMO (Fig. 4a) shows the nanosphere morphology composed with nanosheets. The doped photocatalysts in Fig. 4b–d kept the similar micro-flower morphology. However, with the increase of dopant content, the nanosheets have a tendency to stretching along a specific direction; this stretch phenomenon could lead to more active sites on the surface of N-FMO samples to enhance the activation ability of photo-degradation reaction, and the stretched nanosheets composed with intrinsic nanosphere forming the presented micro-flower morphology. The nanosheets stretched owing to that O2− (132pm) replaced by a bigger anion N3− (171 pm) in the crystal lattice, as a result the volume of nanosheets expansion degree increases with the content of nitrogen until a collapse occurred. Fig. 4e and f show the unformed nanosphere and collapsed nanosheets caused by too much nitrogen. EDX spectrum (Fig. 5 ) was used to confirm that N element was doped into the Fe2(MoO4)3 crystal successfully, and doping content of nitrogen in N-FMO samples was also detected. The signals of N, O, Fe, and Mo can be obviously observed. It was clear that the intensity of nitrogen signal enhanced with the increase of doping content; the detected mass ratio and molar ratio of N: Fe are nearly in keeping with the theoretical value and have been listed in Table 2 . 3.3 Chemical state analysis The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis is used to further characterize the chemical state and chemical composition on the sample surface of pure FMO and N-FMO series photocatalysts. Fig. 5a–d shows the high-resolution XPS spectra of Fe 2p, Mo 3d, O 1s and N 1s of pure FMO and N-doped FMO. The XPS signals of FMO in Fig. 5a were attributed to the Fe 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 states at 723.9 and 711.0eV, respectively. The binding energy values of Mo 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 were observed at 235.58 and 232.45eV, respectively. Fig. 5c shows that the binding energy signal located at 530.0eV fits well with the O 1s state in FMO. The N 1s peak observed at 398eV in Fig. 6d can be attributed to the replacement of nitrogen for oxygen in the crystal lattice of FMO [37]. The lattice introduction of nitrogen constructs Fe-N bonds by the partial replacement of O2− by N3−. The replacement remarkable increase in the electron density on Fe because the smaller electronegativity of the N atom compared with that of O atom [38], which leads to the reduction of Fe 2p binding energy. The similar decrease can be observed in Fig. 6b and c for Mo and O as well, and the shift value was 0.4 and 0.2eV, respectively. It can also be attributed to the surficial chemistry micro-circumstance change of FMO with nitrogen doping. 3.4 Optical properties Pure FMO and N-FMO series photocatalysts optical properties were measured by UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectrometer, the measurement wavelength range from 300 to 800nm (Fig. 7 ). Obviously, nitrogen dopant significantly influences the light absorption ability of original FMO. It can be observed that the optical absorption edge obviously shift towards the visible light direction for the doped samples. The band gap of the semiconductor photocatalysts was calculated using the following equation: Ah ν = α ( h ν − E g ) n / 2 The constant h, α, A, ν, and E g on behalf of the Planck's constant with the unit of eV, the absorption coefficient near the absorption edge, light frequency, the absorption band gap energy, respectively; however, the value of n could be 1 or 4, depending on the transition mode of semiconductor. FMO belongs to direct transition semiconductor, and n is 1 herein [39]. Deep brown color of as-prepared samples was showed in the inset image. As mentioned previously, an important shackle of the application of TiO2 photocatalyst is the poor visible light absorbance. The spectra presented in Fig. 7a showed that FMO series photocatalysts solved this problem perfectly. It can be observed that range from 300nm to about 650nm, FMO series photocatalysts presented strong absorption ability. That is to say, FMO can absorb visible light in the whole region which is in agreement with the deep brown color of samples (Fig. 7b, inset). This fact makes it possible to utilize more visible light to generate photogenerate electron–hole pairs. The band gap energy (E g) of pure FMO and N-FMO series photocatalysts was computed to be close to 2.15eV, and the doped samples have a narrower band gap, which indicated that doping nitrogen has an effect for the enhanced absorbance ability of FMO. Meanwhile, 30at.% N-FMO possesses an outstanding band gap of 2.12eV, which is relatively fit for photocatalytic under visible light. On account of the similar color of pure FMO and N-FMO series photocatalysts, the improvement of visible-light absorption ability could be attributed to doping nitrogen. A mid-gap was introduced in FMO sample to elevate the valence band and resulting in a narrower band gap. 3.5 Photocatalytic properties The photocatalytic performances of the as-prepared samples were evaluated by examining the photodegradation of tetracyclines (TCs) solution under visible light irradiation. Colorless TCs solution valid shield the photo-sensitization effect comparing with traditional organic dye. In a general way, the different amounts of TCs adsorbed on the surface of photocatalysts could significantly influence the photocatalytic performance, so the adsorption rate was evaluated in an adsorption–desorption balance experiment before the introduction of light source [40]. Fig. 8 shows the absorption rate of TCs molecules over different samples, which shows the solution systems almost reached adsorption balance within 20min. The absorption capacity of samples is close to each other, which may because of the electrostatic stabilization of the FMO nanocluster to TCs molecules, and the existence of interaction between FMO and TCs molecules. After the adsorption–desorption equilibrium was achieved, the visible light irradiation was introduced to the photocatalytic system. Fig. 9a shows the photocatalytic performance of prepared samples. It can be observed that all the N-doped FMO samples showed an enhanced photocatalytic ability compared with that of pure FMO. This phenomenon observation implied that nitrogen doped in the crystal lattice played an important role to improve the photocatalytic ability. UV spectra of 30at.% N-FMO which showed the best photocatalytic ability for TCs during the degradation process are also presented in Fig. 9b, the characteristic peak of TCs at the wavelength of 359nm decreases with the visible-light irradiation. The degradation rate of TCs reaches 81% within 90min. It implied that dope of nitrogen in FMO crystal lattice was beneficial to promote the photocatalytic ability of FMO. The stability of the prepared photocatalysts is an important factor for its practical application in environmental service [41]. The photocatalytic stability of N-FMO photocatalysts was confirmed by repeated experiments with 30at.% N-FMO in the TCs degradation. As revealed in Fig. 9c, after three consecutive runs of experiments, no apparent deactivation of the 30at.% N-FMO photocatalyst was found. Therefore, the N-FMO photocatalysts exhibit excellent stability to serve as VLD photocatalysts to regulate environmental pollution. 3.6 Photocatalytic mechanism In summary, the photocatalytic ability of N-FMO samples was highly improved when compared with that of pure FMO. As discussed earlier, such enhancement may come from the depressed recombination of photo-generated electron–hole pairs and the improved light absorption. The 30at.% N-FMO sample presents the best photocatalytic performance with the largest absorption range possibly exhibiting the best photo-generated electron–hole pairs separation rate. It is clearly that the increased range of light absorption is relatively limited; therefore, the main promoted photocatalytic mechanism is possibly come from the depressed electron–hole pairs recombination rate due to the introduction of -3 valence state nitrogen that facilitate electron–hole pairs transfer and depress charge recombination in the FMO. To confirm this, PL spectroscopy with the range from 350 to 700nm was examined for pure FMO and the N-FMO series (Fig. 10 ). The largest peak intensity located at around 470nm attributed to the pure FMO [42], which was also generally the characteristic PL peak of FMO with monoclinic crystal phase [43]. The luminescence fit with the recombination of the hole formed in the O 2p band and the electron in the Mo 3d band. The peak intensity of the PL decreased after the introduction of nitrogen, forming N-FMO series samples. With the increase of the mass ratio of nitrogen from 10% to 30%, the PL peak intensity decreased, and it can be observed that lowest peak was the 30at.% N-FMO. It implied that the separation of the photo-generated electron–hole pairs was greatly promoted. The peak intensity increased again with the increase of nitrogen content. This intensity kept highly consistent with the photocatalytic ability of the samples (Fig. 9a). The photocurrent intensity of the samples in an electrolyte under the irradiation of visible light directly related to the separation ability for the photo-generated electron–hole pairs in the photocatalytic process [44]. Fig. 11 illustrated the photocurrent of pure FMO and 30at.% N-FMO sample when the light was on and off. Obviously, the photocurrent rapid increased and decreased when the light source was introduced and removed. About 30at.% N-FMO sample showed an obvious enhanced photocurrent signal compared with that of pure FMO. This revealed a more effective separation of the photo-generated electron–hole pairs in the 30at.% N-FMO. That is to say, the oxygen vacancy caused by N3− anion trapped active radical successfully. Radical and hole trapping experiments were performed to investigate the main reactive species involved in the photocatalytic process. Three different quenchers, namely, benzoquinone (BQ, 1mM) [45], sodium oxalate (Na2C2O4, 10mM) [46], and isopropanol (IPA, 10mM) [47] were used as the superoxide radical (·O2 −), hole (h+), and hydroxyl radical (·OH) scavengers, respectively. As shown in Fig. 12 , the photocatalytic efficiency of TCs was partially affected by the addition of BQ, implying that ·O2 − was formed from O2 trapped photo-generated electrons in the photocatalytic reaction process. By contrast, after adding IPA, the photocatalytic activity of N-FMO was remarkably depressed. Moreover, there was an evident decrease in the photodegradation rate of TCs when the scavenger Na2C2O4 for h+ was added. These results imply that h+ and ·OH were the major reactive species, whereas ·O2 − had partial impact on the TCs photodegradation process. Based on the mentioned experimental facts, the possible photocatalytic mechanism of N-FMO photocatalyst under visible light irradiation is thereby proposed. Fig. 13 shows the schematic illustration of the mechanism. The photo-generated electrons could transfer to the conduction band (CB) from the valence band (VB) and the holes are formed in the valence band when the N-FMO was irradiated with visible light. Nitrogen presents −3 valence state in the doping behavior, whereas the oxygen replaced by nitrogen presents −2 valence state. In order to balance the redundant electron, oxygen vacancy was formed to modify the surficial chemistry micro-circumstance and photo-generated electrons with negative electricity can be trapped, and lead to a deduction of recombination rate. The separated electrons and holes easily transferred to the oxygen (O2) and water (H2O) absorbed on the surface of N-FMO samples, respectively. Subsequently, the holes reacted with H2O to generate the active hydroxyl radical. The possible process and degradation products were deduced in this study. The process of TCs degradation involved two reaction directions. First, because of the low bond energy of N-C [48], N-methyl group was lost and generates a polar intermediate. Loss of hydroxyl group led to further degradation and generation of intermediate. Secondly, strongly active species (·OH) degraded organic via indirect addition or substitution reaction, which was named as hydroxylation reaction [49]. 1,3-Dipolar cycloaddition generated intermediate towards the C11-C12 double-bond and ·OH at the position C11 reformed would result in the depress of maximum adsorption band of TCs in the 360nm (Fig. 9b) [50]. Produced ·OH further degraded the compounds fragmentation of ring A which was resulted from the hydroxyl groups connected to the degraded aromatic ring D. Moreover, with the increase of hydroxyl group, the intermediate formed by open-ring reaction was able to easier wreck into small molecular intermediates [51]. Related to the experimental results and theory, the possible degradation pathway of TCs is proposed in Fig. 14 . 4 Conclusions By using a hydrothermal method, novel nitrogen doped Fe2(MoO4)3 with flower-like microstructure were successfully prepared. Mid-gap introduced by non-metal element nitrogen efficiently enlarges the visible-light absorption of Fe2(MoO4)3. Profit from the oxygen vacancy modified surficial chemistry micro-circumstance, the recombination rate was valid depressed, so that hydroxyl radical, which plays an important role in tetracyclines degradation reaction can be substantially produced. As a result, all doped samples exhibit the enhanced photocatalytic performance for tetracyclines, and the most enhanced sample was indicated. The process and possible products of N-doped Fe2(MoO4)3 degraded TCs were deduced as well. Both improvement of absorption ability and separation of electron–hole pairs attributed to the introduction of nitrogen. It turns out that N-doped Fe2(MoO4)3 can be a promising function material for tetracyclines degradation. In addition, this work could provide an effective reference for doping non-metallic species for improving the photocatalytic activity of Fe2(MoO4)3. coredata.dc:description: A novel non-metal doped Fe2(MoO4)3 photocatalyst with flower-like microstructure was synthesized by a hydrothermal method. The incorporation location of nitrogen was proved by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) revealed mid-gap from the dope of nitrogen strongly enhanced the visible-light absorption ability. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) showed that the morphology of doped samples was greatly influenced by nitrogen dopant. Significantly, N-doped Fe2(MoO4)3 exhibits an ideal tetracycline (TC) photocatalytic ability, which can be a potential function material for antibiotics degradation. Photoluminescence (PL) and photocurrent indicated that constract of oxygen vacancy, which modified the surficial chemistry micro-circumstance, greatly depressed the recombination rate of the photo-generated electron–hole pairs. In order to investigate the possible mechanism of promoted TC degradation efficiency, radical trapping experiments of pure Fe2(MoO4)3 and N-doped samples were examined. It was found that superoxide radicals (·O2 −) and hydroxyl radical (·OH) formed in the visible light excitation process play an important role in the fragmentation reaction. Moreover, the possible ring-opening intermediates were deduced and a reasonable enhancement mechanism of N-doped Fe2(MoO4)3 TC degradation was also investigated in this study. This investigation could provide an effective reference for doping non-metallic species for improving the photocatalytic activity of Fe2(MoO4)3.
coredata.dc:title: Modified surficial chemistry micro-circumstance and mid-gap effect on photocatalytic ability of tetracycline by introducing of nitrogen in Fe2(MoO4)3
